qa_pairs.question: What was the significance of the 2000 distribution center closure in Homerville, Georgia, and how did this relate to Dollar General's operational and financial developments during that period?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The closure of the distribution center in Homerville, Georgia, in April 2000 was part of Dollar General's operational restructuring, with operations moved to a new distribution center in Alachua, Florida. This move likely aimed to optimize logistics or reduce costs, though the passage does not explicitly state the reasons for the closure.<cite>[S33]</cite></statement> <statement>The closure occurred during a period of significant growth for Dollar General, including the opening of a new corporate headquarters in Goodlettsville, Tennessee, in 2000 and sales exceeding $4 billion by the end of the year, suggesting broader strategic efforts to enhance efficiency and scalability.<cite>[S30][S31]</cite></statement>

Passage 1:
[S1] Dollar General


# Dollar General



**Dollar General Corporation** is an American chain of discount stores headquartered in Goodlettsville, Tennessee. [S2] As of January 8, 2024, Dollar General operated 19,643 stores in the contiguous United States and Mexico. [S3] The company began in 1939 in Scottsville, Kentucky, as a family-owned business called J.L. [S4] Turner and Son, owned by James Luther Turner and Cal Turner. [S5] In 1955, the name changed to Dollar General Corporation, and in 1968 the company went public on the New York Stock Exchange. [S6] The Fortune 500 recognized Dollar General in 1999, and in 2020 it reached #112 on the list. [S7] Dollar General has grown to become one of the most profitable stores in the rural United States, with revenue reaching around $27 billion in 2019. [S8] The company and its business practices have been subject to criticism, particularly regarding how it may be creating and perpetuating food deserts and stifling local businesses while offering fewer and lower-paying jobs. [S9] ## History


### J.L. [S10] Turner and Son: 1939–1964

Dollar General has its origin in Scottsville, Kentucky, with James Luther "J.L." Turner and his son Cal Turner. [S11] James Turner's father died in an accident in 1902 when James was only 11. [S12] James quit school to work on the family farm, helping to provide for his mother and siblings, and subsequently never completed his education. [S13] After two unsuccessful attempts at retailing, James became a traveling dry goods salesman for a Nashville wholesale grocer. [S14] James left the sales job after 10 years and settled his family in Scottsville, Kentucky. [S15] During the Great Depression, he began buying and liquidating bankrupt general stores. [S16] Cal accompanied his father to these closeouts at a young age, gaining valuable business knowledge and skills. [S17] In October 1939, James and Cal opened **J.L. [S18] Turner and Son** with an initial investment of $5,000 each (equivalent to $110,000 in 2023). [S19] The switch to retailing resulted in annual sales above $2 million by the early 1950s. [S20] By the mid-1950s Turner had 35 department stores in Kentucky and Tennessee. [S21] In 1955, Cal Turner developed his idea of a retail store selling goods for a dollar, based on the Dollar Days promotions held at other department stores, by converting Turner's Department Store in Springfield, Kentucky, into the first Dollar General Store. [S22] In 1964, J.L. [S23] Turner died, leaving his son Cal Turner to succeed him. [S24] ### 1968–2002

The company Cal Turner co-founded went public as **Dollar General Corporation** in 1968, posting annual sales of more than $40 million and net income in excess of $1.5 million. [S25] In 1977, Cal Turner Jr., who joined the company in 1965 as a third-generation Turner, succeeded his father as CEO of Dollar General. [S26] In 1989, Cal Sr. [S27] retired as chairman and the company headquarters were moved to Tennessee. [S28] Under his son's leadership, the company grew to more than 6,000 stores and $6 billion in sales. [S29] In 1997 a distribution center was established in South Boston, Virginia. [S30] In 2000, Dollar General opened a new corporate headquarters in Goodlettsville, Tennessee. [S31] By the end of 2000, sales at Dollar General exceeded $4 billion. [S32] The distribution center in Homerville, Georgia, was closed in April 2000 and operations were moved to a new distribution center in Alachua, Florida. [S33] Cal Jr. [S34] retired in 2002 and was succeeded by David Perdue on April 2, 2003. [S35] ### 2003–present

Dollar General entered the grocery market with the establishment of Dollar General Market in 2003. [S36] In 2004, Dollar General expanded to low-cost Asian markets by opening a sourcing office in Hong Kong.

qa_pairs.question: What financial commitments has the Dollar General Literacy Foundation made, and how do they reflect its long-term community impact?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Dollar General Literacy Foundation has committed significant financial support to literacy and education programs, including over $182 million in grants awarded to literacy organizations, which have helped more than 11 million individuals learn to read, prepare for the high school equivalency test, or learn English.<cite>[S127]</cite></statement><statement>In 2020, the Foundation awarded $8.6 million to approximately 970 nonprofit organizations, schools, and libraries, marking its largest one-day grant announcement.<cite>[S128]</cite></statement><statement>In April 2022, the Foundation announced a $9.2 million commitment, with $8.2 million allocated for family literacy programs and $1 million pledged to the DonorsChoose program, highlighting ongoing efforts to expand community impact.<cite>[S130]</cite></statement><statement>These financial commitments reflect the Foundation’s long-term dedication to addressing literacy gaps, as evidenced by its 25th anniversary celebration in 2018 and sustained funding since 1993.<cite>[S125][S129]</cite></statement>

## Subsidiaries


### Dolgencorp

Dolgencorp is a wholly owned subsidiary of Dollar General Corporation. [S121] Dollar General brand products are manufactured under the Dolgencorp subsidiary. [S122] ### Dollar General Global Sourcing Ltd. [S123] In 2004, a Dollar General office was opened in Hong Kong to oversee the global sourcing operations through exporting and importing products of Dollar General–related goods. [S124] ### Dollar General Literacy Foundation

Since 1993, Dollar General has provided funding of literacy and education programs through its subsidiary Dollar General Literacy Foundation. [S125] Every year the Foundation awards funds to nonprofit organizations, schools, and libraries within a 15-mile radius of a Dollar General store or distribution center. [S126] It has awarded more than $182 million in grants to literacy organizations, which have helped more than 11 million individuals learn to read, prepare for the high school equivalency test, or learn English. [S127] In 2020, the Dollar General Literacy Foundation awarded $8.6 million to approximately 970 nonprofit organizations, schools, and libraries, its largest one-day grant announcement. [S128] The Foundation celebrated its 25th anniversary in 2018. [S129] In April 2022, the Dollar General Literacy Foundation announced an approximately $9.2 million commitment to support literacy within the surrounding communities.ᶜˡᵃʳⁱᶠⁱᶜᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ $8.2 million was earmarked for the spring grants to support family literacy programs across the country, while the remaining $1 million was pledged to the DonorsChoose program. [S130] ## Controversies


### Perpetuating economic distress

Passage 2:
[S155] ### *Dollar General Corp. [S156] v. [S157] Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians*


### Pricing irregularities

In March 2023 a Barron's article found that North Carolina, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Arizona together had fined Dollar General more than $1 million for price irregularities during 2021 and 2022, and the company was also facing multiple potential class-action lawsuits relating to the issue. [S158] In 2019, Dollar General was fined $1.75 million by the state of Vermont over pricing irregularities for charging a higher price for products at the register than was advertised at the shelf. [S159] During 2022, the State of Ohio brought a lawsuit for deceptive pricing. [S160] ### Rural and Small Town Resistance

There has been a trend of citizens in small towns organizing to prevent development of Dollar General in towns with a strong rural identity. [S161] The Institute for Local Self Reliance, ILSR, assists communities in rejecting Dollar Store development. [S162] A report by ILSR, The Dollar Store Invasion details the tactics of the dollar chains and the rising grassroots opposition.

[S159] During 2022, the State of Ohio brought a lawsuit for deceptive pricing. [S160] ### Rural and Small Town Resistance

There has been a trend of citizens in small towns organizing to prevent development of Dollar General in towns with a strong rural identity. [S161] The Institute for Local Self Reliance, ILSR, assists communities in rejecting Dollar Store development. [S162] A report by ILSR, The Dollar Store Invasion details the tactics of the dollar chains and the rising grassroots opposition.

qa_pairs.question: What operational changes did Dollar General implement in 2024 regarding self-checkout systems, and how does this relate to its broader expansion and store management strategies outlined in earlier years?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>In 2024, Dollar General shut down self-checkout systems in more than half of its U.S. stores due to losses from theft, as noted in the passage. This decision reflects a shift toward mitigating operational risks and improving profitability. <cite>[S119]</cite></statement> <statement>This operational change aligns with Dollar General’s broader strategies of optimizing store efficiency and managing costs, which were emphasized in earlier expansion plans. For example, prior to 2024, the company focused on opening new stores, remodeling existing locations, and adjusting store formats (e.g., removing pOpshelf stores within DG Market locations) to enhance operational control and customer experience. <cite>[S68][S79]</cite></statement> <statement>These measures, including the 2024 self-checkout shutdown, demonstrate a continued emphasis on balancing growth with fiscal responsibility, as seen in earlier initiatives like the 2019-2020 expansion of produce offerings and store openings in new states. <cite>[S99][S71]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S99] By the end of its 2019 fiscal year, Dollar General offered its produce assortments in more than 650 stores, with plans to expand its produce offerings to an additional 400 stores in fiscal 2020. [S100] ### Private brands

Dollar General has used its abbreviation, the letters "DG", as a store brand for "inexpensive" household products sold through its stores; the brand is in the process of being phased out for most products as of the early 2020s. [S101] DG is also the company's NYSE ticker symbol. [S102] Dollar General private brands include Clover Valley (groceries), Good & Smart (health foods), Smart & Simple (a low-end discount brand), Sweet Smiles (bulk candy), Nature's Menu, Forever Pals and Heartland Farms (pet food and products, formerly EverPet), Gentle Steps (diapers, training pants, and wipes), Studio Selection (beauty and skin care), Believe Beauty (beauty care and makeup), Root to End (hair care), TrueLiving (housewares and laundry), Comfort Bay (towels, blankets, and pillows), Open Trails (men's apparel), Mission Ridge (blue jeans), Zone Pro (sportswear), Rexall (health care, under license from McKesson Corporation), Composure (adult diapers and incontinence pads), Breeze (feminine hygiene), ProEssentials (hardware), DriveMXD (automotive), OfficeHub (office supplies), and Bobbie Brooks (women's apparel, under license). [S103] ### Rexall

The brand name Rexall was first established in 1903 by Louis K. [S104] Liggett and gradually became a powerhouse as a pharmaceutical drug store chain. [S105] Rexall vitamins and supplements began appearing at Dollar General stores in March and by fall 2010 a full line of Rexall products was available at Dollar General. [S106] ## Corporate affairs


### Board of directors

Dollar General Board of Directors as of June 2024 are: Michael M. [S107] Calbert (Chairman of the Board), Todd Vasos (CEO), Warren Bryant, Patricia Fili-Krushel, Timothy I. [S108] McGuire, Ana Chadwick, David Rowland, Debra A. [S109] Sandler, and Ralph E. [S110] Santana. [S111] ### Environmental Impact

Dollar General has implemented several sustainability initiatives as of 2024. [S112] The company has partnered with the Arbor Day Foundation since 2021 to restore over 321 acres of forest and plant more than 96,000 trees near the Mississippi River in Louisiana and Mississippi. [S113] Additionally, Dollar General aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 15% by 2026 and 30% per square foot by 2031. [S114] They have also made significant progress in recycling, avoiding more than 1.1 million metric tons of GHG emissions through various programs such as the cardboard backhauling initiative. [S115] ## Operations

Dollar General has more than 19,400 stores in 48 states, the District of Columbia, and Mexico, and approximately 158,000 employees. [S116] Dollar General also has 17 distribution centers in 16 states. [S117] Since 2017, DG has opened stores in North Dakota, Wyoming, and Washington. [S118] As of early 2025, only two states lacked DG stores: Alaska, and Hawaii. [S119] In the first half of 2024, Dollar General shut down self-checkout in more than half of its stores across the US because of losses from theft.

Passage 2:
[S68] On December 5, 2019, Dollar General announced plans for fiscal 2020 that included the opening of 1,000 new stores, remodeling of 1,500 mature stores, and relocation of 80 stores. [S69] In February 2020, Dollar General announced plans to create 8,000 net new career opportunities in fiscal year 2020. [S70] Dollar General expanded to 46 states in 2020 with the addition of new stores in Wyoming in March and Washington in April. [S71] In late May 2020, two Dollar General stores were destroyed by arson during the George Floyd riots in Minneapolis–Saint Paul, and three others had property damage. [S72] In October 2020, Dollar General opened its first pOpshelf stores in Hendersonville and Clarksville, Tennessee, selling mostly items costing less than $5. [S73] By the end of 2021, the company planned 50 free-standing pOpshelf locations and 25 store-within-a-store locations inside Dollar General Market stores. [S74] In April 2021, the company said it was planning to hire 20,000 employees, less than the number hired in 2020 (50,000). [S75] On 5 March 2022, Dollar General opened its first store in the state of Idaho, located in Athol. [S76] On 12 October 2023, Dollar General announced the return of former CEO Todd Vasos, who replaced Jeff Owen. [S77] Chairman Michael Calbert said in a statement, “At this time the Board has determined that a change in leadership is necessary to restore stability and confidence in the Company moving forward". [S78] In October 2024, it was announced that there are plans for all p0pshelf stores inside DG Market stores to be removed. [S79] ## Major sponsorships


### Auto racing

For several years, Dollar General has had a connection with motorsports, particularly in NASCAR. [S80] The company has previously been a primary sponsor for Joe Gibbs Racing. [S81] Dollar General sponsored Brian Vickers in the Nationwide Series in 2013. [S82] Dollar General became a primary sponsor for Matt Kenseth in the Sprint Cup Series starting in 2013. [S83] Dollar General and Turner (formerly Braun Racing) have been partnered together since 2008, with the team previously sponsoring cars for Frank Cicci Racing and Kevin Harvick Incorporated. [S84] In 2010, Dollar General sponsored some races in the Truck Series for Kyle Busch Motorsports, with Kyle Busch in the No. [S85] 18 Toyota Tundra, and sponsored Kyle Busch's Motorsports No. [S86] 51 Toyota Tundra for four races in 2014, with Busch driving three and Erik Jones driving one. [S87] Dollar General was the title sponsor for Nationwide Series races held in Charlotte every fall, Chicagoland every summer, and Phoenix in the spring. [S88] On May 23, 2016, Dollar General announced it would withdraw its sponsorship from NASCAR at the end of the 2016 season. [S89] Dollar General has also been active in the IndyCar Series since 2008, serving initially as the primary sponsor for owner/driver Sarah Fisher's Sarah Fisher Racing team. [S90] In 2010, both Fisher and Graham Rahal drove part-time for the team, finishing 9th at the Honda Grand Prix of St. [S91] Petersburg. [S92] Fisher also led the field at the Peak Antifreeze & Motor Oil Indy 300 at Chicagoland Speedway. [S93] In 2011, Dollar General continued to sponsor Sarah Fisher Racing; the team was still part-time, but Ed Carpenter drove for nines races starting at the 2011 Indianapolis 500. [S94] Dollar General ceased its sponsorship of Sarah Fisher Racing in 2012. [S95] ### Sports

Dollar General became the sponsor of the Dollar General Bowl, formerly the GoDaddy Bowl, in Mobile, Alabama, on August 17, 2016. [S96] In May 2019, Dollar General withdrew its title sponsorship of the Mobile bowl game. [S97] ## Merchandise

Dollar General sells products from national name brands like Clorox, Energizer, Procter & Gamble, Hanes, Coca-Cola, Mars, Unilever, Nestlé, Kimberly-Clark, Kellogg's, General Mills, and PepsiCo. [S98] In 2018, Dollar General expanded its product offerings to include the "Better for You" assortment, which aims to offer healthier options from brands like Kashi, Annie's, Back to Nature, and Kind.

qa_pairs.question: How did Dollar General's strategic decisions, such as store closures and distribution center expansions, interact with its financial and safety challenges as outlined in the source?
qa_pairs.answer:
<statement>Dollar General's strategic decisions, such as store closures and distribution center expansions, were part of its operational restructuring and growth strategy. For instance, the closure of over 400 stores under the "EZ Stores" evaluation model (S42) aimed to optimize profitability by relocating or closing locations that failed criteria like profitability and infrastructure (S41). These closures coincided with financial challenges, including a $162 million settlement for accounting irregularities in 2001 (S140) and earnings restatements due to financial misreporting (S141). However, the passage does not explicitly link store closures directly to these financial issues, instead framing them as part of a broader operational assessment.</statement><cite>[S40][S41][S42][S140][S141]</cite>

<statement>The expansion of distribution centers, such as the 12th in 2014 (S46) and the 13th in 2016 (S51), likely supported Dollar General's growth strategy, including store openings and supply chain efficiency. However, these expansions occurred alongside persistent safety challenges, as evidenced by repeated OSHA violations, including fines for unsafe conditions like blocked fire exits and electrical hazards (S143–S154). While the passage does not explicitly connect distribution center expansions to safety issues, the financial and safety challenges appear as separate but concurrent issues affecting the company’s operations.</statement><cite>[S46][S51][S143][S144][S145][S147][S154]</cite>

[S37] On June 21, 2007, CEO David Perdue announced his resignation, leaving David Bere as interim CEO. [S38] One month later, all shares of Dollar General stock were acquired by private equity investors for $22 per share. [S39] An investment group consisting of affiliates of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (KKR), GS Capital Partners (an affiliate of Goldman Sachs), Citigroup Private Equity, and other co-investors completed an acquisition of Dollar General Corporation for $6.9 billion. [S40] As a part of the transition to a privately held company, Dollar General assessed each location at the end of its lease against a model known as "EZ Stores". [S41] This assessment included evaluating whether the location had a loading dock, garbage dumpsters, adequate parking, and acceptable profitability. [S42] Stores that did not pass this evaluation were relocated or closed. [S43] Over 400 stores were closed as part of this initiative. [S44] Dollar General filed on August 20, 2009, for an initial public offering of up to $750 million, turning the company once again into a publicly traded corporation. [S45] In 2013, Dollar General started selling cigarettes in response to its competitor Family Dollar selling cigarettes in 2012. [S46] Dollar General's 12th distribution center opened on May 31, 2014, in Bethel, Pennsylvania, to serve the Northeast and Midwest stores. [S47] On August 18, 2014, Dollar General lodged a competing bid of $9.7 billion against Dollar Tree for Family Dollar. [S48] The bid was rejected on August 20, 2014, by the Family Dollar board, which said it would proceed with the deal with Dollar Tree. [S49] On June 3, 2015, Chief Operating Officer Todd Vasos replaced Rick Dreiling as chief executive. [S50] Dreiling remained as senior advisor and chairman until his retirement in January 2016. [S51] Dollar General's 13th distribution center opened in San Antonio, Texas, on June 6, 2016, with a local investment of $100 million and the creation of over 500 jobs. [S52] In September 2015, the City Council in Janesville, Wisconsin, approved an agreement to bring a Dollar General distribution center to the town. [S53] The center created more than 500 jobs in the area and became the 14th Dollar General distribution center. [S54] On September 15, 2016, Dollar General announced plans to hire 10,000 new employees and open 900 new stores in fiscal 2016 and 1,000 in fiscal 2017. [S55] Dollar General operated 13,000 stores as of August 2016. [S56] In January 2017, Dollar General opened a concept store in Nashville, Tennessee, called DGX. [S57] The DGX store concept focuses on urban shoppers and is geared toward instant-consumption services such as coffee stations and soda fountains. [S58] The following month another DGX store opened in Raleigh, North Carolina, and in September a third DGX opened in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. [S59] As of May 2020, Dollar General operated 12 DGX locations in nine states. [S60] In Jackson, Georgia, Dollar General opened its 15th distribution center in fall 2017 to serve stores in Georgia and the surrounding states. [S61] In 2017, Dollar General began construction for its 16th distribution center, in Amsterdam, New York. [S62] The distribution center was to cost $91 million and was expected to create 400 jobs in Montgomery County, New York. [S63] Dollar General planned to open 900 new stores in 2018. [S64] The distribution center became fully operational in 2019. [S65] Also in 2017, Dollar General acquired stores from Dollar Express, a spinoff from the Family Dollar–Dollar Tree deal, and converted the store. [S66] In September 2019, Dollar General celebrated the grand opening of its 16,000th store, in Panama City, Florida, following damage sustained from Hurricane Michael in October 2018. [S67] To commemorate the opening, Dollar General presented two $16,000 checks in partnership with Kellogg's to two local elementary schools displaced from the hurricane.

Passage 2:
[S131] Dollar General, along with other dollar store chains, while "sometimes [filling] a need in cash-strapped communities" where supermarkets have closed, are regarded not "merely a byproduct of economic distress. [S132] They're a cause of it." Dollar store chains, in "capitalizing on a series of powerful economic and social forces—white flight, the recent recession, the so-called "retail apocalypse"—all of which have opened up gaping holes in food access...might not be causing these inequalities per se, they appear to be perpetuating them". [S133] The rapid growth in dollar stores across the US has created food deserts and a "dollar store belt". [S134] After originally granting them local tax incentives, a number of municipalities have been adding zoning bylaws to discourage dollar stores. [S135] ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ) According to a study done by the Institute for Local Self-Reliance, dollar stores tend to create fewer and lower-wage jobs than independent grocery stores. [S136] The report claims that dollar stores stifle local competition, thereby hurting the communities they are serving. [S137] In March 2020, Dollar General announced plans for its 2020 fiscal year to begin offering produce assortments at approximately 400 stores in addition to the 650 stores that already did so. [S138] In February 2019, the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, published a story which found that the quality of fruits and vegetables at dollar stores is just as good as at regular grocery stores. [S139] ### Financial irregularities

On April 30, 2001, Dollar General Corp was judged liable for making false statements or failing to disclose adverse facts about the company's financial results, and paid $162 million for settlement. [S140] The company also announced a restatement of its earnings for the previous three fiscal years, due to accounting irregularities including allegations of fraudulent behavior. [S141] On March 3, 2005, Dollar General restated its results for 2000 through 2003, due to a clarification of lease-accounting matters issued by the SEC. [S142] ### OSHA fines

In November 2014, Dollar General was fined $51,700 by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) following an inspection of a Brooklyn, Mississippi, branch of the store. [S143] The statement from OSHA noted that Dollar General had had repeated health and safety violations: "Since 2009, OSHA has conducted 72 inspections of Dollar General nationwide. [S144] Of those inspections, 39 have resulted in citations." In April 2016, OSHA reported that further citations had been given to the store for exposing employees to the risk of electrical hazards due to missing face plates on electrical outlets. [S145] The store was fined $107,620. [S146] In December 2016, OSHA noted that some Dollar General stores continued to block fire exits with merchandise in disregard of safety violations, resulting in several fines. [S147] Inspections at Dollar General stores in 2022 in Pembroke in February, and Hogansville and Smyrnaᶜˡᵃʳⁱᶠⁱᶜᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ in March, identified four willful and seven repeat violations. [S148] Specifically, OSHA cited the company for failing to keep receiving areas clean and orderly and for stacking materials in an unsafe manner. [S149] These hazards exposed workers to slips, trips, and being struck by objects. [S150] OSHA also issued citations for exposing workers to fire and entrapment hazards by failing to keep exit routes and electrical panels clear and unobstructed. [S151] Dollar General's pattern of disregarding worker safety was apparent at five other Southeast locations. [S152] In February 2022, OSHA proposed $1,048,309 in penalties after inspections at three locations in Mobile, Alabama, and one in Dalton, Georgia, found similar hazards. [S153] At another Mobile location, a December 2021 inspection led OSHA to propose $321,827 in penalties for exposing workers to slip and trip hazards and not keeping the main storeroom orderly to allow a safe exit during an emergency. [S154] In March 2023 it was reported that Dollar General was added to OSHA's severe-violator enforcement program.

[S49] On June 3, 2015, Chief Operating Officer Todd Vasos replaced Rick Dreiling as chief executive. [S50] Dreiling remained as senior advisor and chairman until his retirement in January 2016. [S51] Dollar General's 13th distribution center opened in San Antonio, Texas, on June 6, 2016, with a local investment of $100 million and the creation of over 500 jobs. [S52] In September 2015, the City Council in Janesville, Wisconsin, approved an agreement to bring a Dollar General distribution center to the town. [S53] The center created more than 500 jobs in the area and became the 14th Dollar General distribution center. [S54] On September 15, 2016, Dollar General announced plans to hire 10,000 new employees and open 900 new stores in fiscal 2016 and 1,000 in fiscal 2017. [S55] Dollar General operated 13,000 stores as of August 2016. [S56] In January 2017, Dollar General opened a concept store in Nashville, Tennessee, called DGX. [S57] The DGX store concept focuses on urban shoppers and is geared toward instant-consumption services such as coffee stations and soda fountains. [S58] The following month another DGX store opened in Raleigh, North Carolina, and in September a third DGX opened in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. [S59] As of May 2020, Dollar General operated 12 DGX locations in nine states. [S60] In Jackson, Georgia, Dollar General opened its 15th distribution center in fall 2017 to serve stores in Georgia and the surrounding states. [S61] In 2017, Dollar General began construction for its 16th distribution center, in Amsterdam, New York. [S62] The distribution center was to cost $91 million and was expected to create 400 jobs in Montgomery County, New York. [S63] Dollar General planned to open 900 new stores in 2018. [S64] The distribution center became fully operational in 2019. [S65] Also in 2017, Dollar General acquired stores from Dollar Express, a spinoff from the Family Dollar–Dollar Tree deal, and converted the store. [S66] In September 2019, Dollar General celebrated the grand opening of its 16,000th store, in Panama City, Florida, following damage sustained from Hurricane Michael in October 2018. [S67] To commemorate the opening, Dollar General presented two $16,000 checks in partnership with Kellogg's to two local elementary schools displaced from the hurricane.

[S131] Dollar General, along with other dollar store chains, while "sometimes [filling] a need in cash-strapped communities" where supermarkets have closed, are regarded not "merely a byproduct of economic distress. qa_pairs.question: What were the key financial and regulatory challenges faced by Dollar General, and how did they impact the company's public perception and operations?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Dollar General faced significant financial challenges, including a $162 million settlement in 2001 for making false statements about its financial results and restating earnings due to accounting irregularities and fraudulent behavior. These issues likely damaged its public perception as a reliable corporate entity.<cite>[S140][S141]</cite></statement> <statement>The company also encountered regulatory challenges, particularly with repeated violations of occupational safety standards by OSHA. For example, in 2014, Dollar General was fined $51,700 for health and safety violations, and by 2022, it was added to OSHA's severe-violator enforcement program due to ongoing hazards like blocked fire exits and unsafe storage practices.<cite>[S143][S147][S153]</cite></statement> <statement>These financial and regulatory issues impacted Dollar General's operations by necessitating costly settlements, operational overhauls to meet safety standards, and a tarnished public image. Additionally, the company's expansion into areas with food deserts and its role in stifling local competition drew criticism, further affecting its reputation.<cite>[S131][S136][S137]</cite></statement>

[S52] In September 2015, the City Council in Janesville, Wisconsin, approved an agreement to bring a Dollar General distribution center to the town. [S53] The center created more than 500 jobs in the area and became the 14th Dollar General distribution center. [S54] On September 15, 2016, Dollar General announced plans to hire 10,000 new employees and open 900 new stores in fiscal 2016 and 1,000 in fiscal 2017. [S55] Dollar General operated 13,000 stores as of August 2016. [S56] In January 2017, Dollar General opened a concept store in Nashville, Tennessee, called DGX. [S57] The DGX store concept focuses on urban shoppers and is geared toward instant-consumption services such as coffee stations and soda fountains. [S58] The following month another DGX store opened in Raleigh, North Carolina, and in September a third DGX opened in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. [S59] As of May 2020, Dollar General operated 12 DGX locations in nine states. [S60] In Jackson, Georgia, Dollar General opened its 15th distribution center in fall 2017 to serve stores in Georgia and the surrounding states. [S61] In 2017, Dollar General began construction for its 16th distribution center, in Amsterdam, New York. [S62] The distribution center was to cost $91 million and was expected to create 400 jobs in Montgomery County, New York. [S63] Dollar General planned to open 900 new stores in 2018. [S64] The distribution center became fully operational in 2019. [S65] Also in 2017, Dollar General acquired stores from Dollar Express, a spinoff from the Family Dollar–Dollar Tree deal, and converted the store. [S66] In September 2019, Dollar General celebrated the grand opening of its 16,000th store, in Panama City, Florida, following damage sustained from Hurricane Michael in October 2018. [S67] To commemorate the opening, Dollar General presented two $16,000 checks in partnership with Kellogg's to two local elementary schools displaced from the hurricane.

Passage 2:
[S131] Dollar General, along with other dollar store chains, while "sometimes [filling] a need in cash-strapped communities" where supermarkets have closed, are regarded not "merely a byproduct of economic distress. [S132] They're a cause of it." Dollar store chains, in "capitalizing on a series of powerful economic and social forces—white flight, the recent recession, the so-called "retail apocalypse"—all of which have opened up gaping holes in food access...might not be causing these inequalities per se, they appear to be perpetuating them". [S133] The rapid growth in dollar stores across the US has created food deserts and a "dollar store belt". [S134] After originally granting them local tax incentives, a number of municipalities have been adding zoning bylaws to discourage dollar stores. [S135] ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ) According to a study done by the Institute for Local Self-Reliance, dollar stores tend to create fewer and lower-wage jobs than independent grocery stores. [S136] The report claims that dollar stores stifle local competition, thereby hurting the communities they are serving. [S137] In March 2020, Dollar General announced plans for its 2020 fiscal year to begin offering produce assortments at approximately 400 stores in addition to the 650 stores that already did so. [S138] In February 2019, the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, published a story which found that the quality of fruits and vegetables at dollar stores is just as good as at regular grocery stores. [S139] ### Financial irregularities

On April 30, 2001, Dollar General Corp was judged liable for making false statements or failing to disclose adverse facts about the company's financial results, and paid $162 million for settlement. [S140] The company also announced a restatement of its earnings for the previous three fiscal years, due to accounting irregularities including allegations of fraudulent behavior. [S141] On March 3, 2005, Dollar General restated its results for 2000 through 2003, due to a clarification of lease-accounting matters issued by the SEC. [S142] ### OSHA fines

In November 2014, Dollar General was fined $51,700 by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) following an inspection of a Brooklyn, Mississippi, branch of the store. [S143] The statement from OSHA noted that Dollar General had had repeated health and safety violations: "Since 2009, OSHA has conducted 72 inspections of Dollar General nationwide. [S144] Of those inspections, 39 have resulted in citations." In April 2016, OSHA reported that further citations had been given to the store for exposing employees to the risk of electrical hazards due to missing face plates on electrical outlets. [S145] The store was fined $107,620. [S146] In December 2016, OSHA noted that some Dollar General stores continued to block fire exits with merchandise in disregard of safety violations, resulting in several fines. [S147] Inspections at Dollar General stores in 2022 in Pembroke in February, and Hogansville and Smyrnaᶜˡᵃʳⁱᶠⁱᶜᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ in March, identified four willful and seven repeat violations. [S148] Specifically, OSHA cited the company for failing to keep receiving areas clean and orderly and for stacking materials in an unsafe manner. [S149] These hazards exposed workers to slips, trips, and being struck by objects. [S150] OSHA also issued citations for exposing workers to fire and entrapment hazards by failing to keep exit routes and electrical panels clear and unobstructed. [S151] Dollar General's pattern of disregarding worker safety was apparent at five other Southeast locations. [S152] In February 2022, OSHA proposed $1,048,309 in penalties after inspections at three locations in Mobile, Alabama, and one in Dalton, Georgia, found similar hazards. [S153] At another Mobile location, a December 2021 inspection led OSHA to propose $321,827 in penalties for exposing workers to slip and trip hazards and not keeping the main storeroom orderly to allow a safe exit during an emergency. [S154] In March 2023 it was reported that Dollar General was added to OSHA's severe-violator enforcement program.

Then, in March 2005, they restated results again because of lease-accounting matters from the SEC. These financial issues likely hurt their public perception, making them look unreliable or unethical.

Next, looking at regulatory challenges. The OSHA fines are mentioned multiple times. For example, in November 2014, they were fined $51,700 for health and safety violations. There were repeated inspections with citations, and in 2022, they had significant fines and were added to OSHA's severe-violator program. These regulatory issues would damage their reputation as a company that doesn't prioritize worker safety, potentially leading to loss of trust and possible legal repercussions.

Another point is the acquisition by private equity in 2007. While that's more of a corporate move, it might relate to financial challenges. The company went private, which could be a response to financial pressures, and then went public again in 2009. The closure of over 400 stores in 2007 as part of the transition to private ownership might indicate operational challenges, possibly due to financial strain.

Also, the part about Dollar General being part of creating food deserts and facing zoning bylaws in some municipalities. This is more about public perception and regulatory challenges. The study from the Institute for Local Self-Reliance says they create fewer jobs and hurt local competition, which could affect their public image as a negative force in communities.

The financial irregularities and OSHA violations are the main points. The citations for these issues would impact both their operations (having to pay fines, improve safety) and public perception (seen as irresponsible or unsafe). The closure of stores and acquisitions might also be part of their operational challenges, but the main financial and regulatory issues are the settlements and OSHA fines.

qa_pairs.question: How did Dollar General's approach to store locations and distribution centers, including the 'EZ Stores' evaluation, affect its market presence and community relations?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Dollar General's evaluation of store locations through the "EZ Stores" model, which assessed factors like loading docks, garbage dumpsters, parking, and profitability, led to the relocation or closure of over 400 stores. This strategy likely streamlined operations but may have reduced its market presence in certain areas by decreasing the number of physical locations.<cite>[S40][S42][S43]</cite></statement><statement>The closures of underperforming stores could have negatively impacted community relations, as Dollar General was criticized for contributing to economic distress in cash-strapped communities by perpetuating inequalities and creating food deserts, despite filling some needs.<cite>[S132][S133][S135]</cite></statement><statement>Dollar General's expansion of distribution centers, such as the 12th in Bethel, Pennsylvania, and the 13th in San Antonio, Texas, likely enhanced its market presence by improving supply chain efficiency and supporting new store openings, which may have offset some losses from store closures.<cite>[S46][S51]</cite></statement><statement>However, the company faced scrutiny over labor practices, including OSHA violations, which could have harmed community relations by raising concerns about workplace safety and job quality in the areas where its stores and distribution centers operated.<cite>[S143][S145][S152]</cite></statement>

[S1] Dollar General


# Dollar General



**Dollar General Corporation** is an American chain of discount stores headquartered in Goodlettsville, Tennessee. [S2] As of January 8, 2024, Dollar General operated 19,643 stores in the contiguous United States and Mexico. [S3] The company began in 1939 in Scottsville, Kentucky, as a family-owned business called J.L. [S4] Turner and Son, owned by James Luther Turner and Cal Turner. [S5] In 1955, the name changed to Dollar General Corporation, and in 1968 the company went public on the New York Stock Exchange. [S6] The Fortune 500 recognized Dollar General in 1999, and in 2020 it reached #112 on the list. [S7] Dollar General has grown to become one of the most profitable stores in the rural United States, with revenue reaching around $27 billion in 2019. [S8] The company and its business practices have been subject to criticism, particularly regarding how it may be creating and perpetuating food deserts and stifling local businesses while offering fewer and lower-paying jobs. [S9] ## History


### J.L. [S10] Turner and Son: 1939–1964

Dollar General has its origin in Scottsville, Kentucky, with James Luther "J.L." Turner and his son Cal Turner. [S11] James Turner's father died in an accident in 1902 when James was only 11. [S12] James quit school to work on the family farm, helping to provide for his mother and siblings, and subsequently never completed his education. [S13] After two unsuccessful attempts at retailing, James became a traveling dry goods salesman for a Nashville wholesale grocer. [S14] James left the sales job after 10 years and settled his family in Scottsville, Kentucky. [S15] During the Great Depression, he began buying and liquidating bankrupt general stores. [S16] Cal accompanied his father to these closeouts at a young age, gaining valuable business knowledge and skills. [S17] In October 1939, James and Cal opened **J.L. [S18] Turner and Son** with an initial investment of $5,000 each (equivalent to $110,000 in 2023). [S19] The switch to retailing resulted in annual sales above $2 million by the early 1950s. [S20] By the mid-1950s Turner had 35 department stores in Kentucky and Tennessee. [S21] In 1955, Cal Turner developed his idea of a retail store selling goods for a dollar, based on the Dollar Days promotions held at other department stores, by converting Turner's Department Store in Springfield, Kentucky, into the first Dollar General Store. [S22] In 1964, J.L. [S23] Turner died, leaving his son Cal Turner to succeed him. [S24] ### 1968–2002

The company Cal Turner co-founded went public as **Dollar General Corporation** in 1968, posting annual sales of more than $40 million and net income in excess of $1.5 million. [S25] In 1977, Cal Turner Jr., who joined the company in 1965 as a third-generation Turner, succeeded his father as CEO of Dollar General. [S26] In 1989, Cal Sr. [S27] retired as chairman and the company headquarters were moved to Tennessee. [S28] Under his son's leadership, the company grew to more than 6,000 stores and $6 billion in sales. [S29] In 1997 a distribution center was established in South Boston, Virginia. [S30] In 2000, Dollar General opened a new corporate headquarters in Goodlettsville, Tennessee. [S31] By the end of 2000, sales at Dollar General exceeded $4 billion. [S32] The distribution center in Homerville, Georgia, was closed in April 2000 and operations were moved to a new distribution center in Alachua, Florida. [S33] Cal Jr. [S34] retired in 2002 and was succeeded by David Perdue on April 2, 2003. [S35] ### 2003–present

Dollar General entered the grocery market with the establishment of Dollar General Market in 2003. [S36] In 2004, Dollar General expanded to low-cost Asian markets by opening a sourcing office in Hong Kong.

[S37] On June 21, 2007, CEO David Perdue announced his resignation, leaving David Bere as interim CEO. [S38] One month later, all shares of Dollar General stock were acquired by private equity investors for $22 per share. [S39] An investment group consisting of affiliates of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (KKR), GS Capital Partners (an affiliate of Goldman Sachs), Citigroup Private Equity, and other co-investors completed an acquisition of Dollar General Corporation for $6.9 billion. [S40] As a part of the transition to a privately held company, Dollar General assessed each location at the end of its lease against a model known as "EZ Stores". [S41] This assessment included evaluating whether the location had a loading dock, garbage dumpsters, adequate parking, and acceptable profitability. [S42] Stores that did not pass this evaluation were relocated or closed. [S43] Over 400 stores were closed as part of this initiative. [S44] Dollar General filed on August 20, 2009, for an initial public offering of up to $750 million, turning the company once again into a publicly traded corporation. [S45] In 2013, Dollar General started selling cigarettes in response to its competitor Family Dollar selling cigarettes in 2012. [S46] Dollar General's 12th distribution center opened on May 31, 2014, in Bethel, Pennsylvania, to serve the Northeast and Midwest stores. [S47] On August 18, 2014, Dollar General lodged a competing bid of $9.7 billion against Dollar Tree for Family Dollar. [S48] The bid was rejected on August 20, 2014, by the Family Dollar board, which said it would proceed with the deal with Dollar Tree. [S49] On June 3, 2015, Chief Operating Officer Todd Vasos replaced Rick Dreiling as chief executive. [S50] Dreiling remained as senior advisor and chairman until his retirement in January 2016. [S51] Dollar General's 13th distribution center opened in San Antonio, Texas, on June 6, 2016, with a local investment of $100 million and the creation of over 500 jobs. [S52] In September 2015, the City Council in Janesville, Wisconsin, approved an agreement to bring a Dollar General distribution center to the town. [S53] The center created more than 500 jobs in the area and became the 14th Dollar General distribution center. [S54] On September 15, 2016, Dollar General announced plans to hire 10,000 new employees and open 900 new stores in fiscal 2016 and 1,000 in fiscal 2017. [S55] Dollar General operated 13,000 stores as of August 2016. [S56] In January 2017, Dollar General opened a concept store in Nashville, Tennessee, called DGX. [S57] The DGX store concept focuses on urban shoppers and is geared toward instant-consumption services such as coffee stations and soda fountains. [S58] The following month another DGX store opened in Raleigh, North Carolina, and in September a third DGX opened in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. [S59] As of May 2020, Dollar General operated 12 DGX locations in nine states. [S60] In Jackson, Georgia, Dollar General opened its 15th distribution center in fall 2017 to serve stores in Georgia and the surrounding states. [S61] In 2017, Dollar General began construction for its 16th distribution center, in Amsterdam, New York. [S62] The distribution center was to cost $91 million and was expected to create 400 jobs in Montgomery County, New York. [S63] Dollar General planned to open 900 new stores in 2018. [S64] The distribution center became fully operational in 2019. [S65] Also in 2017, Dollar General acquired stores from Dollar Express, a spinoff from the Family Dollar–Dollar Tree deal, and converted the store. [S66] In September 2019, Dollar General celebrated the grand opening of its 16,000th store, in Panama City, Florida, following damage sustained from Hurricane Michael in October 2018. [S67] To commemorate the opening, Dollar General presented two $16,000 checks in partnership with Kellogg's to two local elementary schools displaced from the hurricane.

[S68] On December 5, 2019, Dollar General announced plans for fiscal 2020 that included the opening of 1,000 new stores, remodeling of 1,500 mature stores, and relocation of 80 stores. [S69] In February 2020, Dollar General announced plans to create 8,000 net new career opportunities in fiscal year 2020. [S70] Dollar General expanded to 46 states in 2020 with the addition of new stores in Wyoming in March and Washington in April. [S71] In late May 2020, two Dollar General stores were destroyed by arson during the George Floyd riots in Minneapolis–Saint Paul, and three others had property damage. [S72] In October 2020, Dollar General opened its first pOpshelf stores in Hendersonville and Clarksville, Tennessee, selling mostly items costing less than $5. [S73] By the end of 2021, the company planned 50 free-standing pOpshelf locations and 25 store-within-a-store locations inside Dollar General Market stores. [S74] In April 2021, the company said it was planning to hire 20,000 employees, less than the number hired in 2020 (50,000). [S75] On 5 March 2022, Dollar General opened its first store in the state of Idaho, located in Athol. [S76] On 12 October 2023, Dollar General announced the return of former CEO Todd Vasos, who replaced Jeff Owen. [S77] Chairman Michael Calbert said in a statement, “At this time the Board has determined that a change in leadership is necessary to restore stability and confidence in the Company moving forward". [S78] In October 2024, it was announced that there are plans for all p0pshelf stores inside DG Market stores to be removed. [S79] ## Major sponsorships


### Auto racing

For several years, Dollar General has had a connection with motorsports, particularly in NASCAR. [S80] The company has previously been a primary sponsor for Joe Gibbs Racing. [S81] Dollar General sponsored Brian Vickers in the Nationwide Series in 2013. [S82] Dollar General became a primary sponsor for Matt Kenseth in the Sprint Cup Series starting in 2013. [S83] Dollar General and Turner (formerly Braun Racing) have been partnered together since 2008, with the team previously sponsoring cars for Frank Cicci Racing and Kevin Harvick Incorporated. [S84] In 2010, Dollar General sponsored some races in the Truck Series for Kyle Busch Motorsports, with Kyle Busch in the No. [S85] 18 Toyota Tundra, and sponsored Kyle Busch's Motorsports No. [S86] 51 Toyota Tundra for four races in 2014, with Busch driving three and Erik Jones driving one. [S87] Dollar General was the title sponsor for Nationwide Series races held in Charlotte every fall, Chicagoland every summer, and Phoenix in the spring. [S88] On May 23, 2016, Dollar General announced it would withdraw its sponsorship from NASCAR at the end of the 2016 season. [S89] Dollar General has also been active in the IndyCar Series since 2008, serving initially as the primary sponsor for owner/driver Sarah Fisher's Sarah Fisher Racing team. [S90] In 2010, both Fisher and Graham Rahal drove part-time for the team, finishing 9th at the Honda Grand Prix of St. [S91] Petersburg. [S92] Fisher also led the field at the Peak Antifreeze & Motor Oil Indy 300 at Chicagoland Speedway. [S93] In 2011, Dollar General continued to sponsor Sarah Fisher Racing; the team was still part-time, but Ed Carpenter drove for nines races starting at the 2011 Indianapolis 500. [S94] Dollar General ceased its sponsorship of Sarah Fisher Racing in 2012. [S95] ### Sports

Dollar General became the sponsor of the Dollar General Bowl, formerly the GoDaddy Bowl, in Mobile, Alabama, on August 17, 2016. [S96] In May 2019, Dollar General withdrew its title sponsorship of the Mobile bowl game. [S97] ## Merchandise

Dollar General sells products from national name brands like Clorox, Energizer, Procter & Gamble, Hanes, Coca-Cola, Mars, Unilever, Nestlé, Kimberly-Clark, Kellogg's, General Mills, and PepsiCo. [S98] In 2018, Dollar General expanded its product offerings to include the "Better for You" assortment, which aims to offer healthier options from brands like Kashi, Annie's, Back to Nature, and Kind.

[S99] By the end of its 2019 fiscal year, Dollar General offered its produce assortments in more than 650 stores, with plans to expand its produce offerings to an additional 400 stores in fiscal 2020. [S100] ### Private brands

Dollar General has used its abbreviation, the letters "DG", as a store brand for "inexpensive" household products sold through its stores; the brand is in the process of being phased out for most products as of the early 2020s. [S101] DG is also the company's NYSE ticker symbol. [S102] Dollar General private brands include Clover Valley (groceries), Good & Smart (health foods), Smart & Simple (a low-end discount brand), Sweet Smiles (bulk candy), Nature's Menu, Forever Pals and Heartland Farms (pet food and products, formerly EverPet), Gentle Steps (diapers, training pants, and wipes), Studio Selection (beauty and skin care), Believe Beauty (beauty care and makeup), Root to End (hair care), TrueLiving (housewares and laundry), Comfort Bay (towels, blankets, and pillows), Open Trails (men's apparel), Mission Ridge (blue jeans), Zone Pro (sportswear), Rexall (health care, under license from McKesson Corporation), Composure (adult diapers and incontinence pads), Breeze (feminine hygiene), ProEssentials (hardware), DriveMXD (automotive), OfficeHub (office supplies), and Bobbie Brooks (women's apparel, under license). [S103] ### Rexall

The brand name Rexall was first established in 1903 by Louis K. [S104] Liggett and gradually became a powerhouse as a pharmaceutical drug store chain. [S105] Rexall vitamins and supplements began appearing at Dollar General stores in March and by fall 2010 a full line of Rexall products was available at Dollar General. [S106] ## Corporate affairs


### Board of directors

Dollar General Board of Directors as of June 2024 are: Michael M. [S107] Calbert (Chairman of the Board), Todd Vasos (CEO), Warren Bryant, Patricia Fili-Krushel, Timothy I. [S108] McGuire, Ana Chadwick, David Rowland, Debra A. [S109] Sandler, and Ralph E. [S110] Santana. [S111] ### Environmental Impact

Dollar General has implemented several sustainability initiatives as of 2024. [S112] The company has partnered with the Arbor Day Foundation since 2021 to restore over 321 acres of forest and plant more than 96,000 trees near the Mississippi River in Louisiana and Mississippi. [S113] Additionally, Dollar General aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 15% by 2026 and 30% per square foot by 2031. [S114] They have also made significant progress in recycling, avoiding more than 1.1 million metric tons of GHG emissions through various programs such as the cardboard backhauling initiative. [S115] ## Operations

Dollar General has more than 19,400 stores in 48 states, the District of Columbia, and Mexico, and approximately 158,000 employees. [S116] Dollar General also has 17 distribution centers in 16 states. [S117] Since 2017, DG has opened stores in North Dakota, Wyoming, and Washington. [S118] As of early 2025, only two states lacked DG stores: Alaska, and Hawaii. [S119] In the first half of 2024, Dollar General shut down self-checkout in more than half of its stores across the US because of losses from theft.

## Subsidiaries


### Dolgencorp

Dolgencorp is a wholly owned subsidiary of Dollar General Corporation. [S121] Dollar General brand products are manufactured under the Dolgencorp subsidiary. [S122] ### Dollar General Global Sourcing Ltd. [S123] In 2004, a Dollar General office was opened in Hong Kong to oversee the global sourcing operations through exporting and importing products of Dollar General–related goods. [S124] ### Dollar General Literacy Foundation

Since 1993, Dollar General has provided funding of literacy and education programs through its subsidiary Dollar General Literacy Foundation. [S125] Every year the Foundation awards funds to nonprofit organizations, schools, and libraries within a 15-mile radius of a Dollar General store or distribution center. [S126] It has awarded more than $182 million in grants to literacy organizations, which have helped more than 11 million individuals learn to read, prepare for the high school equivalency test, or learn English. [S127] In 2020, the Dollar General Literacy Foundation awarded $8.6 million to approximately 970 nonprofit organizations, schools, and libraries, its largest one-day grant announcement. [S128] The Foundation celebrated its 25th anniversary in 2018. [S129] In April 2022, the Dollar General Literacy Foundation announced an approximately $9.2 million commitment to support literacy within the surrounding communities.ᶜˡᵃʳⁱᶠⁱᶜᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ $8.2 million was earmarked for the spring grants to support family literacy programs across the country, while the remaining $1 million was pledged to the DonorsChoose program. [S130] ## Controversies


### Perpetuating economic distress

[S131] Dollar General, along with other dollar store chains, while "sometimes [filling] a need in cash-strapped communities" where supermarkets have closed, are regarded not "merely a byproduct of economic distress. [S132] They're a cause of it." Dollar store chains, in "capitalizing on a series of powerful economic and social forces—white flight, the recent recession, the so-called "retail apocalypse"—all of which have opened up gaping holes in food access...might not be causing these inequalities per se, they appear to be perpetuating them". [S133] The rapid growth in dollar stores across the US has created food deserts and a "dollar store belt". [S134] After originally granting them local tax incentives, a number of municipalities have been adding zoning bylaws to discourage dollar stores. [S135] ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ) According to a study done by the Institute for Local Self-Reliance, dollar stores tend to create fewer and lower-wage jobs than independent grocery stores. [S136] The report claims that dollar stores stifle local competition, thereby hurting the communities they are serving. [S137] In March 2020, Dollar General announced plans for its 2020 fiscal year to begin offering produce assortments at approximately 400 stores in addition to the 650 stores that already did so. [S138] In February 2019, the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, published a story which found that the quality of fruits and vegetables at dollar stores is just as good as at regular grocery stores. [S139] ### Financial irregularities

On April 30, 2001, Dollar General Corp was judged liable for making false statements or failing to disclose adverse facts about the company's financial results, and paid $162 million for settlement. [S140] The company also announced a restatement of its earnings for the previous three fiscal years, due to accounting irregularities including allegations of fraudulent behavior. [S141] On March 3, 2005, Dollar General restated its results for 2000 through 2003, due to a clarification of lease-accounting matters issued by the SEC. [S142] ### OSHA fines

In November 2014, Dollar General was fined $51,700 by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) following an inspection of a Brooklyn, Mississippi, branch of the store. [S143] The statement from OSHA noted that Dollar General had had repeated health and safety violations: "Since 2009, OSHA has conducted 72 inspections of Dollar General nationwide. [S144] Of those inspections, 39 have resulted in citations." In April 2016, OSHA reported that further citations had been given to the store for exposing employees to the risk of electrical hazards due to missing face plates on electrical outlets. [S145] The store was fined $107,620. [S146] In December 2016, OSHA noted that some Dollar General stores continued to block fire exits with merchandise in disregard of safety violations, resulting in several fines. [S147] Inspections at Dollar General stores in 2022 in Pembroke in February, and Hogansville and Smyrnaᶜˡᵃʳⁱᶠⁱᶜᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ in March, identified four willful and seven repeat violations. [S148] Specifically, OSHA cited the company for failing to keep receiving areas clean and orderly and for stacking materials in an unsafe manner. [S149] These hazards exposed workers to slips, trips, and being struck by objects. [S150] OSHA also issued citations for exposing workers to fire and entrapment hazards by failing to keep exit routes and electrical panels clear and unobstructed. [S151] Dollar General's pattern of disregarding worker safety was apparent at five other Southeast locations. [S152] In February 2022, OSHA proposed $1,048,309 in penalties after inspections at three locations in Mobile, Alabama, and one in Dalton, Georgia, found similar hazards. [S153] At another Mobile location, a December 2021 inspection led OSHA to propose $321,827 in penalties for exposing workers to slip and trip hazards and not keeping the main storeroom orderly to allow a safe exit during an emergency. [S154] In March 2023 it was reported that Dollar General was added to OSHA's severe-violator enforcement program.

[S155] ### *Dollar General Corp. [S156] v. [S157] Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians*


### Pricing irregularities

In March 2023 a Barron's article found that North Carolina, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Arizona together had fined Dollar General more than $1 million for price irregularities during 2021 and 2022, and the company was also facing multiple potential class-action lawsuits relating to the issue. [S158] In 2019, Dollar General was fined $1.75 million by the state of Vermont over pricing irregularities for charging a higher price for products at the register than was advertised at the shelf. [S159] During 2022, the State of Ohio brought a lawsuit for deceptive pricing. [S160] ### Rural and Small Town Resistance

There has been a trend of citizens in small towns organizing to prevent development of Dollar General in towns with a strong rural identity. [S161] The Institute for Local Self Reliance, ILSR, assists communities in rejecting Dollar Store development. [S162] A report by ILSR, The Dollar Store Invasion details the tactics of the dollar chains and the rising grassroots opposition.
